Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Level Response Diversity: Land Use, Livelihood Diversification and Resilience in northern Tanzania

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Paul Leslie (Carolina Population Center, the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill) and Dr. J. Terrence McCabe (University of Colorado) will undertake research on how variation in household and community responses to environmental changes and policy constraints affect the overall resilience of socio-ecological systems, and the role of cultural institutions in those systems. Data to develop models to explore these issues will be collected in Tanzania. Throughout much of East Africa, traditionally nomadic and semi-nomadic herders have been adopting agriculture and engaging in labor migration. The environmental and social consequences of these changes are likely to be profound but remain poorly understood. This project will clarify the causes of the changing land use and livelihood patterns, and will explore how these changes affect the social-ecological system, including the viability of households and communities and the impacts on land cover and biodiversity. A particular focus will be response diversity. Response diversity results from the fact that not all actors (individuals, households, communities) respond the same way to changing conditions; the variation in response may be more important than the typical or average response in understanding the effects of decision making under changing conditions.

The project is innovative in its integration of empirical field-based research with agent-based modeling (ABM), a computer simulation technique that is well-suited to studying complex systems in which households and communities interact with one another and make decisions influenced by changing conditions. Used together, these methods will reveal much about how land use, livelihoods, family demography, population growth and other factors respond to changes in the physical and political-economic environment, especially unpredictable fluctuations and shocks that test overall system resilience. Shocks can be climatic (e.g., severe droughts), biotic (e.g., livestock disease epidemics), and sociopolitical (e.g., loss of access to pasture and other resources when conservation areas are established).

The scientific significance of this research lies in its contribution to understanding and theorizing the very complex effects of response diversity on socio-ecological resilience. The research results will have a direct bearing on conservation and development in East Africa and will also help to understand changing socio-ecological systems elsewhere. The researchers' findings also will suggest ways of mitigating the potentially negative impacts of social and ecological change on human well-being while also promoting effective conservation and development measures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were twofold. First: to clarify the causes of the changing livelihood patterns of Maasai in northern Tanzania and to explore how these changes are likely to affect the social-ecological system, including the viability of households and communities and the implication for social/ecological system resilience. A particular focus was on the role that response diversity plays in shaping those changes and their consequences. The second goal of this project was to develop an agent-based model (ABM) of the interactions among the social and ecological components of the Simanjiro social-ecological system and similar systems. 

The research revealed that changing livelihood patterns were due to changes in how the land is used at both household and village scales. Especially important are issues concerning how villages are allocating land to households; how some individuals and large scale organizations have gained access to large land holdings; and how livelihoods have diversified through cultivation and labor migration. Access to land has emerged as a driving force with population increase and fragmentation due to the formation of new households, the splitting of villages, the establishment of a large commercial ranch and conservation efforts. The research team also examined the process of migration which included the migration of young men to work as guards in urban areas and the migration of young and older men to become middlemen in the tanzanite gem trade. The researchers  have seen a diversity of responses to changing conditions at all scales (households, sub-villages and village), and early indications are that this diversity in responses does contribute to the overall resilience of social/ecological systems in the rangelands of northern Tanzania. Due to health difficulties of the PI (Paul Leslie) the agent based model is still being developed. Once fully developed the researchers will be able to test how different environment conditions and policy scenarios impact resilience at various scales.

The results of this research project have been presented at major national conferences and in university settings. Publications resulting from this project have appeared in major anthropological journals -- Current Anthropology, Human Organization and Human Ecology – and have contributed both theoretically and empirically to the discipline.

Graduate students at both the University of Colorado and the University of North Carolina were also trained on the project. The team has also worked with faculty and graduate students at the University of Dar es Salaam and McCabe served as a co-advisor for a Masters level student in the Department of Zoology and Wild Conservation at the University of Dar es Salaam.
